questions.stem: When taking instructions in custody, which is the best first step before discussing interview strategy?

options.text: Tell the client to answer all questions to look cooperative
Get the client's account, clarify key facts, and confirm what the police allegation is (disclosure) as far as available
Promise the client they will be released if they follow your advice
Avoid asking questions in case the client says something unhelpful

questions.explanation: Effective advice depends on understanding the allegation and the client’s account. You should take clear instructions, identify key facts/risks, and only then advise on strategy. Avoid guarantees or coercive advice.

references.cite: Client care: taking instructions and documenting advice (Check: guidance)
PACE 1984 s.58 (private consultation)

questions.stem: Which note is most useful to protect both you and the client if they reject your advice?

options.text: A brief note: 'Client didn’t listen'
A detailed note of the advice, key risks explained, the client’s decision, and confirmation they understood
No note — it’s confidential anyway
A note blaming the police for the client’s decision

questions.explanation: Contemporaneous notes of advice and informed instructions are critical. They support professional standards, reduce disputes, and help later case handling and portfolio evidence.

references.cite: Record keeping: attendance notes and advice/instructions (Check: guidance)
PACE 1984 s.58 (private consultation)

questions.stem: Which statement best reflects confidentiality in a private legal consultation at the police station?

options.text: Everything said must always be disclosed to police
Confidentiality applies; you should not disclose without lawful basis, subject to limited exceptions
Confidentiality does not apply in custody
Confidentiality only applies after charge

questions.explanation: Consultations are confidential as a core principle (often protected by privilege), but there are limited and context-dependent exceptions. As a rule, do not disclose without a clear lawful/ethical basis.

references.cite: Confidentiality / privilege in police station advice (Check: guidance)
SRA Principles and Codes of Conduct

questions.stem: A police officer asks you to 'have a quiet word' with the client to admit the offence to speed things up. What is the best response?

options.text: Agree and pressure the client to admit, to keep a good relationship with police
Explain you will take instructions and advise independently; you cannot pressure or mislead the client
Tell the officer you will only help if they give full disclosure
Withdraw immediately without explanation

questions.explanation: Your duty is to the client. You should remain professional and independent, take instructions, and advise on the basis of law/process and the client’s account—without pressure or improper influence.

references.cite: Professional conduct: independence and client-focused advice (Check: guidance)
SRA Principles and Codes of Conduct

questions.stem: Which is the biggest professional risk of 'coaching' a client during interview (e.g., mouthing answers, signaling)?

options.text: It makes the interview shorter
It can undermine the integrity of the interview and expose you to misconduct allegations
It guarantees the client will not be charged
It is required to protect the client

questions.explanation: Coaching is improper and can damage both the client’s case and your professional position. The correct approach is to advise in consultation and intervene on procedural/fairness grounds, not to supply answers during interview.

references.cite: Professional standards: conduct during interview attendance (Check: guidance)
SRA Principles and Codes of Conduct

questions.stem: If you believe a client may be vulnerable (e.g., learning disability), which approach best balances confidentiality and safeguarding?

options.text: Ignore it — vulnerability is only for the police to assess
Raise safeguarding needs through proper channels (e.g., request AA/healthcare assessment) while keeping the consultation content confidential
Disclose everything the client said to police to protect them
End the consultation immediately and leave

questions.explanation: You can and should request appropriate safeguards (AA, interpreter, healthcare) without disclosing confidential instructions. Use the custody process to secure protections while maintaining confidentiality.

references.cite: Code C — vulnerable suspects and safeguards (Check: paragraph)
Code C para 1.4 and Annex E (definition of vulnerable person)

questions.stem: Which is the best way to check a client understands your advice in custody?

options.text: Ask them to repeat back the key points in their own words
Assume they understand because they nodded
Avoid checking understanding to save time
Only ask if the police are present

questions.explanation: A simple teach-back check helps confirm informed instructions and reduces misunderstanding, especially under stress or where there may be vulnerability.

references.cite: Client communication and informed instructions (Check: guidance)
SRA Code of Conduct — client care
